The goal of Conversational Coding is to broaden computer literacy. We help beginning programmers "level-up," by identifying the important stepping-stones they should land on at each stage in their learning journey, so that they can boost themselves further and quicker.

02 Sep 2014

In the previous lesson on HTTP, we learned what HTTP is and how it’s part of the communication systems that tie browsers and websites (and web applications) together. We saw how to look at the HTTP requests being generated by a browser when loading a webpage.

What is HTTP? How Web Applications and Browsers Communicate

01 Sep 2014

Web applications are typically written as computer programs that run constantly, waiting for requests from browsers running on other computers. Those computers can be someone’s desktop, laptop, or mobile phone. The browser requests are usually made by a human being who clicks on a link in a webpage (or in her email,) and expects to see a webpage as a result. The job of the web application is to respond with the code corresponding to the webpage that the browser can interpret correctly.

Read more...

Parsing the HTML to a DOM Tree

27 Aug 2014

The hierarchical structure of an HTML page is usually accessed via a data structure called the DOM. Most programming languages have libraries that let you convert an HTML page into a DOM. Why do we do this? HTML pages are just a long list of textual characters - for a programming language to understand what elements (another word for tags) are contained in the document, the text has to be parsed into a format that’s easier for a script to manipulate. The DOM is one such format.

Read more...
